newsitem.title: USA: Natgas futures still down late on cash.
newsitem.headline: Natgas futures still down late on cash.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures, pressured by soft swing prices, stayed mostly lower late Friday, but some expected a slight rebound before the close as shorts covered ahead of the holiday weekend.
At 1400 EDT, Oct was still down by 2.7 cents at $1.88 per million British thermal units, while November was 1.6 cents lower at $2.03. Others were steady to off by three cents.

"The market is oversold and there's pretty good support in the $1.85-1.86 area (in Oct). I don't think I'd want to go home short for the (U.S. Labor Day) holiday in front of the storms," said one Houston-based trader.

While Hurricane Edouard offered no threat to the U.S. Gulf, forecasters were monitoring Hurricane Fran, which was 215 miles north-northeast of Antigua at 1100 EDT, with winds of 75 mph moving northwest at nine mph. The storm was not expected to gain any strength in the next day.
Next was Tropical Storm Gustav, about 970 miles west of the Cape Verde islands at 1100 EDT but losing steam.
Though there was little extreme weather on the horizon, traders said even warmer temperatures next week could help September prices as flows begin, particularly after this week's very mild weather.
But few saw any reason for a significant rally near-term.

September cash prices at the Gulf notionally fell a couple of cents Friday to the mid-$1.70s, with swing prices in the $1.60-1.70 area. Midcon prices were steady to up slightly in the low-to-mid $1.60s.
Technically, traders pegged October support at yesterday's low of $1.85 and then at $1.82. Resistance was seen first at $1.955 and then in the $2.08-2.09 area.
NYMEX said 6,306 Henry Hub contracts traded at 1340 EDT.
NYMEX October Permian natgas was off two cents at $1.56, with November still 3.5 cents lower at $1.67. NYMEX said 45 lots traded at 1340 EDT.
On the KCBT, October eased 0.2 cent to $1.64, while deferreds were one-half to two cents lower. The East/West spread narrowed by 2.5 cents to 24 cents (NYMEX premium).
NYMEX and KCBT will be closed Monday for the U.S. Labor Day holiday.
